title: Never mind the races, what about the food?
text:
And after the four “crazy” days of the carnival, it all comes crashing down again. Until next year.

Here’s a quick look at what’s going down at a few of the main pop-ups next week – because quite the best thing about being in the Birdcage is ogling all the hats. The chef’s hats, that is.

Landmark by Lexus

Matt Stone and Jo Barrett are bringing Australian ingredients to the table at the Lexus marquee.

As principal partner of the Victoria Racing Club, Lexus gets prime real estate, a mammoth, three-storey build and some seriously in-demand chefs as their brand ambassadors, backed up by The Big Group.

Translating the brand’s values – Japanese hospitality and craftsmanship, Australian sustainability and native ingredients – onto the plate this time round will be Matt Stone and Jo Barrett of Yarra Valley’s Oakridge (smoked trout and caraway croissant; spent gin orange parfait); Neil Perry (bento boxes from Saké, fresh crumpets, a BLT and gnocchi fritter with prosciutto from R Bar at Crown) and, on the ground level, the team from Eazy Peazy, serving up yakitori fresh off the hibachi grill.

Gin orange parfait with poppy seed and cultured butter, anyone?

Plus, guests can grab a glass of wellness at low-alcohol bar Byrdi, or just soak up the booze with Neil’s race-day faves of sausage rolls, finger sandwiches and fries with togarashi.

“By 3pm, no one’s gluten-free any more,” says The Big Group’s executive chef Lisa Bolle. “They’re all smashing cheeseburgers by then.”

Biggest change the caterers have seen over the past couple of years?

Advertisement

“The rise of vegans and social influencers,” says Bolle. “The influencers just take photos of the food and don’t eat it. And they don’t engage with anyone, either.”

Maison Mumm Hotel

Dan Hong puts the finishing touches to delectables designed for Maison Mumm Hotel.

The Melbourne Cup Carnival marks the official launch down south of made by Merivale, the off-site catering branch of Justin Hemmes’ all-conquering Sydney restaurant group. And the jewel in the racing crown for the newbies is the Maison Mumm Hotel, claimed to be “the first luxury hotel-inspired marquee” in the Birdcage. Your personal chef during your stay? Dan Hong, fresh from opening new restaurant Lotus 2.0 in Sydney’s Potts Point.

“I’m not in my comfort zone, that’s for sure,” says Hong of his four-day gig. “For one I’m in Melbourne, and second, the kitchen is a trestle table out the back.”

Still, it’s likely he’ll pull himself together in time to get into the “fun, party, champagne-and-dancing” swing of things. Among Hong’s Asian-inflected, Mumm-friendly food will be duck rillettes banh mi with pickled carrot, daikon and coriander; and crispy bug tails wrapped in brik pastry with seaweed salt and saffron aioli. And for the hotel’s super-exclusive, secret RSRV room? Prestige Mumm Cuvées and choux puffs with lobster, lime, crème fraiche and caviar.

No word yet on whether guests can check in for an overnight stay, however.

Tabcorp

Expect Italian delights including casarecce with spiced veal ragu from Guy Grossi. Simon Schluter

No collection of pop-ups would be complete without a nod to the year’s hottest restaurant trend, Italian. Enter Tabcorp, with Cup veteran Guy Grossi in the Italian corner and desserts maestro Darren Purchese, of Burch & Purchese, flying the Aussie flag. Well, it’s just the spot to have a bet each way. And that means saddling up with casarecce with spiced veal ragu; crocchette di baccalà; milk bun with cotoletta and Italian slaw; and winding down at the marquee’s champagne and pavlova bar.

Advertisement

“An iconic Australian dessert for an iconic Australian event!” says Purchese, who’ll also be serving his signature tube desserts including coconut, passionfruit, ginger and mint, and explosive raspberry.

Peter Rowland's golden beetroot croissant filled with hummus and walnut salsa.

Our pick of the food

Golden beetroot “croissant” – Peter Rowland

Official VRC catering partner since 1996, Peter Rowland is this year taking its first-class food to a wider audience at Flemington by catering to private parties in The Rails (aka the car park). PR executive chef Matthew Haigh’s golden beetroot “croissant” is a tiny delight, a visual play on the pastry wrapped around Milawa blue cheese.

Falafel fattoush with green tahini and pickled radish – The Big Group

One of the more substantial dishes from The Big Group, and very Yotam Ottolenghi. The mini falafel balls are as light as air, the tahini stripes add richness and the acid balance of the salad is spot-on. It’s also vegan and gluten-free.

Lady Helena’s Eton Mess – food &desire

Eton Mess is one of those adaptable sweets that can either be simple or complex. This version is firmly in the latter camp, with so many different elements the result is as much like trifle as Eton Mess. You might think that a collision of white and lavender meringue clouds, candied rose petals, freeze-dried fruits, passionfruit curd, vanilla bean cream, lemon mist and rose oil would be all a bit OTT, but you’d be wrong. It’s sensational, and not too sweet. Find it at 1 Oliver Street, one of two marquees serviced by Birdcage first-timer food &desire.

Chicken sandwich – Peter Rowland

Line up all the Peter Rowland chicken sandwiches that get eaten every year at Spring Carnival time and they’d go round the track two-and-a-half times. We love a cute statistic, and we love this sambo – so simple, so perfect. And this year, for the first time, they’re making a gluten-free version, a “chicken glass sandwich”, with crispy chicken skin standing in for the bread.
description: If you’re lucky enough to enjoy the Melbourne Cup from the Birdcage, expect an extra treat this year: the culinary form has never looked so good.
